comment._content: www.worthpoint.com/worthopedia/c1913-rppc-general-maximo-... has a small image of a picture that might have been taken on the same occasion. Information there includes: "'MAXIMO CASTILLO' ~ ostensibly taken while he was under guard at FORT BLISS, TEXAS ~ General Maximo Castillo - for a while, was one of Pancho Villa's men, and was also known as a 'gentleman' train robber -- he robbed the Americans but did not harm them ~ he died in Cuba in 1919"

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: www.produccionesalianza.mex.tl/176993_Maximo-Castillo-El-... has a lot of information about Castillo in Spanish -- which I do not read. However using Google's translation service, it would appear that Castillo wrote his memoirs while imprisoned in the US and gave the manuscript to his wife when she visited him in Fort Wingate (where he was transferred form Fort Bliss) in 1915. He was eventually released and went to Havana, where he died in 1919.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Vargas Valdés, Jesús. Máximo Castillo y la Revolución en Chihuahua. Nueva Vizcaya Ediciones, Chihuahua, México 2003. The automatically translated text of a blurb for this book at www2.uacj.mx/uehs/Publicaciones/OtrasPublicaciones.htm suggests that this publication makes use of the memoirs he wrote while imprisoned.
